So subject to that small change, are you happy to move, Clare? Clare, thank you. Roger, second. All those in favour, say aye. Aye. Against, carried. Wonderful. So that leads us to our first substantive item, which is the Te Rata water tower removal and underlying land reclassification. I believe, Anna McElrey, this is your item to present. Good morning.
speaker: suemilner

text: Morena, Susan, Morena, Councillors, the purpose of this report is to seek the committee's approval to remove the redundant Kihikihi Water Tower on Tūrata and repurpose the area, which is the town's key vantage point to a viewing, picnicking area where the history of the site can be shared. I'll take the report as read and then only highlight some key points and also talk to the recent correspondence from Angela Brown, who's the secretary  of the Police Cottage Temple House Trust, and also a discussion that I've recently had with Rachel Darmody from Heritage New Zealand. So back when I first started in 2019, a project was initiated by council to start the enhancement of Turata's grazed area to open it up for public access and to improve its amenity for the 2020 Land War commemorations. That included removal of the grazing and associated infrastructure  removal of pest plants, and improvements to the boundary fencing. As part of this work, we commissioned a visual structural assessment of the water tower to determine if we needed to temporarily fence it off to ensure public safety. The assessment, which is included in Appendix 2, confirmed we didn't need to. We then started to think about the long-term future of the tower. The tower was built in 1948 and commissioned in 1951. It's been redundant for some time.  And while it does represent Kihiki's first town water supply, Rachel Darmody from Heritage New Zealand confirmed it wouldn't be protected under heritage legislation. She noted that, as we've said on the report, we will need to follow that standard process of working with archaeologists on the methodology and to apply for Heritage New Zealand authority if there is ground disturbance as part of that removal.  The Reserve Management Plan, which was adopted in 2013, clearly sets the intention to remove the tower. Staff are aware of mixed views in the community about this through discussions with the Police Cottage Temple Trust and the recent LTP process. In light of this, Community Services reviewed three options and they are set out in Appendix 1.  We've concluded that the management plan is still an operative document, and that the high immediate costs of removing the tower are offset by the creation of a destination that will provide panoramic views of Kihiki out to the Waipā's maunga, and also give us the opportunity to share the history of the area. It will also remove a redundant asset, which in the long term may present quite significant costs to retain in situ. The water's team are supportive of this  position that we've reached and have agreed to fund the removal of the tower. The Te Aumutu Community Board and Kiki Rape Hazards and Residents Association are supportive of this option as our mana whenua. The Police Cottage Temple House Trust however are not and have communicated that many of the Main Street business owners that they've contacted are also not. The Trust want the tower retained and are supportive of the Lions Club's proposal to pay for a mural on the tower.  The meeting attendees agreed to request that Council not make a decision yet on the tower's future until a public meeting at Kiiki could be held.  We've considered that request, and we still feel that, given the management plan is still an operative document, it was prepared following two rounds of public consultation, and that there's sufficient information for council to make a decision on this project. So I'll finish there, and happily respond to any questions.
speaker: annamcelrea

text: Thanks for that, Anna. Does anybody have a question for Anna in respect of this? Marcus, then Bruce, and Clare.
speaker: suemilner

text: Yeah, it's a great report. Thank you, Anna. And I think it does reflect what the community of Kiki wants. Yeah, as Dad said, he remembers it being built and stuff, and it's just a concrete tower that doesn't really add value to the reserve. So we can use that space more efficiently.

text: Cool, excellent. So yeah, obviously the executive summary, we're going to talk about the non-financial and the financial report.  First one, total visitors. Obviously we're up last year. The previous year had a major COVID impact. And we had six weeks worth of the Cambridge Pool opening or the new Peri Aquatic Centre opening in the last of the financial year, which was about 21, just over 21,000 people. So that contributed to it. So obviously our busiest year, but not really a full indication of both facilities operating.  And this is the event center only, total visitors. So we're roughly, obviously, if we look at, I've done three years worth of COVID impact, and we're roughly the year before the same. So, which is kind of nice because we also had some impact of visitors. They obviously would go to the periodic center as well. So we've seen those numbers dwindle a little bit. And obviously, COVID's had a lot of impact on our  Stadium side, so events and just regular community events. So tracking roughly about the year before COVID entered. The pools, so the Livingstone Aquatics at TA Events Centre. Roughly the previous year before those impacts, so we're tracking around the same. Stadium, obviously the last two years  COVID's had a major impact. And so our challenges are around that and gatherings and social distancing. And I've had a number of events impacted as well. So it is frustrating in trying to get them back, but hopefully we won't be too long. And well, I'm in Hamilton, so I'm impacted at the moment. The Club Waipā, so we did quite well with Club Waipā, but that would also help some of the Cambridge people  join the club wiper for the benefits that it gets for them. So tracking pretty well. Group fitness classes were obviously down slightly because once again, COVID has an impact on those and those are the one of the first things to be cancelled due to physical distancing and hygiene and things like that. Peri Aquatic Center. So I did  The final year that we were open for the season, that was a four month period. And you can see with the new facility in the six weeks comparison there, obviously that's 2017 and 18 year compared to the six weeks that we were open. So four months compared to the six weeks.  Swim Waipā, that's been our golden child, I guess, or the highlight. Swim Waipā has done really well, expanded into the community. Our programs, we got quite a bit of funding, 30 or so thousand to run the Swim for Life and Boat Safety and those type of programs for the community schools. We put through 12, sorry,  3,000, three and a half, just under three and a half thousand through that schools program. And we're quite proud of that, which is up from 2,400 the previous year. So it's up 30% on that in overall, quite a bit through the squads and the learn to swim program. Health and safety. Once again, always a challenge for us.  Being a community facility and the nature of our facility, they're all pretty good. But if you can see, most of the tracking has tracked down. Contaminations are around the same as last year, with an extra six weeks from Cambridge being on and more people. So we were recently, you know, proud of trying to keep them as low as possible and things like that. We had no notifiable event and one ambulance in that period of time.  But most of them are just general first aid bumps, cuts, things like that, locks.

text: Thank you.  Thanks very much, Justine. Best of luck for your new position and you'll obviously be greatly missed. Thank you. I'll see you guys a bit later. All right then. So moving on then to the next item on our agenda, which is the submission on proposed changes to wetland regulations. And for that one, we have Graeme Pollard. Is Graeme floating around somewhere here?
speaker: suemilner

text: I certainly am. If I can get my video on, there you go. I'm afraid after Justine, you've got me. Good morning.  Graham? Yeah, am I on? Yes, I am. Yes, good morning, councillors. I hope you're all well. I'm stuck in level three. I'm one of those people that are already on the dark side. This is a report that's seeking the committee's feedback, comments, and or endorsement of a draft submission to the Ministry of the Environment's  proposed changes to the wetlands regulations. The proposals and the submission fall into three sections. The third section relates to consenting pathways with which we're in general support. I'm hoping Tony Quickfall's available to answer any questions that you may have on these proposals. Hilary Webb, our biodiversity planner, is also available to answer any queries on the other two sections.  Now the second section relates to better provisions for the restoration and maintenance of wetlands and biosecurity activities. The submission is supportive of the changes that make it easier to carry out those restoration and biosecurity activities. However, we do seek greater clarity on who is authorized to carry out restoration and maintenance work in wetlands and under what mandate.  because as written, the proposals specify council plans, which gives the potential to exclude documents like EWE management plans. Therefore, in the submission, we seek greater clarity and the ability to work with a wider and more considered range of management plans. The first section of the proposals is concerned with the definition of natural wetland.  Now here the submission does not agree with the proposals, and let me just run through why that's the case. The Resource Management Act, the National Environmental Standard for Freshwater, and the National Policy Statement for Freshwater Management, in conjunction with the wetland delineation protocols, already provide a clear, sound, legislation-based definition, including pasture  In that definition would introduce confusion ambiguity and lack of clarity in the definition. And it potentially works against landowners by potentially exposing them to the risk of legal action for undertaking management of a site is not actually a natural wetland it's just a vague definition as a as a pasture, so we think that a clear well defined and ambiguous definition of natural wetland.  is beneficial for council in identifying and monitoring significant natural areas, and should it be necessary, hopefully not, but should it be necessary, enforcing compliance with the district plan. So using a combination of vegetation, hydrology and soils produces a good objective technical definition, including pasture,  will make definition to subjective and vague and potentially costly, not just for Council, but for landowners to engage consultants in determining what is and is not a natural wetland. So hopefully that gives some background to where we're coming from. The submission, the draft submission is the appendix to the report. And  We're very happy to take on any comments, answer any questions. I hope my backup team is actually in place.
